title: Cadet sergeant posed as girl to trick teenage boys into sex games
text:
Jamie Hopes, 24, an Army cadet trainer, has been jailed for four years at Cardiff Crown Court (Picture: PA)

An Army cadet sergeant who tricked more than 40 teenage boys into sex games via social media has been jailed for four years.

Jamie Hopes, 24, pretended to be a 15-year-old girl to get his victims to film sex acts.

Cardiff Crown Court heard Hopes – a training sergeant with the Army Cadet Force – had a file called ‘For Baiting’ where he kept photos and graphic videos of a teenage girl to deceive boys.

At least 40 young victims were targeted and that the ‘vast majority’ were filmed performing sex acts, the court was told.

Hopes, of Maesteg, South Wales, was tracked down by police after they traced a graphic Tumblr video to his IP address.

When Hopes was confronted at the home he shared with his parents, he told officers: ‘Yes, I know what you’re talking about, it will be on my mobile.’

Police found two devices containing more than 50,000 indecent videos and images, and evidence Hopes had also shared material with fellow online paedophiles.

He pleaded guilty to 15 charges including causing or inciting a child to engage in sexual activity, possession of indecent images of child, distributing indecent images of a child and possession of extreme pornography.

He was sentenced to four years’ imprisonment and made subject of a 10-year Sexual Harm Prevention to prevent him contacting anyone under 18.

He will also remain on the Sex Offenders’ Register indefinitely.

After the hearing, Detective Constable Carl Taylor, said: ‘Hopes targeted dozens of teenage boys on popular social networking sites, gaining their trust by pretending to be a girl their own age, and grooming and manipulating them in to engaging in sexual acts.

‘Our team have not been able to identify all of those affected by Hopes’ offending, but of those we’ve managed to trace, all have suffered greatly and the abuse has had a profound effect on them.

‘I welcome this sentencing, and I hope it provides those victims with some closure and allows them to begin rebuilding their lives.’
